author: nick.odio
title: Ferrum's Staking as a Service MS3&4
description: Early stage projects lack token utility. Staking as a Service solutions can solve this. There are 0 white label staking providers on Cardano

f6_assessments.q0:
Ferrum is a staking solution present since 2018, with services offered for ETH, MATIC, BSC and AVAX. With this proposal they are asking for funding to analyze the scope of a potential integration with Cardano. Following this initial effort, this might (or not) materialize into high potential areas to be later on built / integrated.  

I am not convinced that there is a good fit of the proposal with the challenge. Since Ferrum is not convinced yet that there is a potential to be integrated with Cardano, I think the ball lies within Ferrum’s court in order to take a very good look at their actual services and future development plans and come up with viable avenues for integration. This argument should also be analyzed at the same time with the fuzzy budget logic that renders the project highly unfeasible - see below. Unclear potential, so 3 stars I think are appropriate.
f6_assessments.q1: The team behind Ferrum seems very strong, and they have made an excellent effort into presenting themselves. From a budgetary point of view, this proposal is unique, unfortunately, since it has used absolutely no figures whatsoever. The entire budget section is simply an argument as to why granting the funds is necessary in order for Ferrum “to be able to justify prioritizing this integration [...]  cognizant of their backlog”. Rephrasing the argument, for me it sounds more like “we are not entirely sure that there is a business case to be made here, but if you fund us we shall make an effort”. This is a very weak argument, to say the least, and renders the proposal completely infeasible.
f6_assessments.q2: The team uses SCRUM and runs 2 week sprints. They promise an open sourced Jira board to track the progress of each task and they also promise to to provide Progress reports and financial reports every month. The team’s approach to openness is transparency is duly noted and the Cardano community would most likely not have any issues in tracking this project, if funded.

f6_assessments.q0: The purpose of the proposal is to create an environment for the community to staking and through that to earn rewards at the end of the staking period. Some notable points in this proposal, for example, Liquidity StakingLiquidity has the ability to bring far greater rewards, VIP StakingVIP Staking only addresses on the allowed list can participate in the project, this contributes to increasing community credibility. The goal and solution of this proposal are consistent with the requirements of the challenge. The proposed solution lists activities to find vulnerabilities in features or in security and thereby continuously improve to give customers the most effective product. However, there aren't any metrics or impact metrics to allow me to make an accurate judgment. In addition, the risks that will be encountered during project development as well as the ways to overcome them are clearly stated.
f6_assessments.q1: Team members have accumulated skills and expertise from a variety of fields. However, no links are provided such as Linkldn or twitter,... against which to verify the experience and skills of the team. The team's milestones are clearly divided, but no timeline is given. This will be detrimental to the quality assessment and the community will not be able to track the progress of the project. The purpose of the given budget is to be used to fund the development of resources to integrate Ferrum's Staking Service solutions with Cardano, unfortunately, the article did not state what the estimated budget is as well as how will the budget allocation be done.
f6_assessments.q2: The writer mentions providing Catalyst with an open sourced Jira board, which will provide a monthly progress report as well as an indication of how the funds are allocated. This will allow the community to understand in detail how the project is progressing and in what direction it is heading. The team is expected to achieve 10s of millions in TVL in 2022, but I do not see any relevant indicators as well as identify the risks that will occur to increase the feasibility and ensure the community. can assess whether the project implementation is on schedule or not.

f6_assessments.q0:
This is a second part proposal from the Ferrum's Staking as a Service MS1&2 (https://cardano.ideascale.com/c/idea/398807), which repeats exactly the same impact wording as the other. So my assessment is exactly the same (as it shall).
As a technology & company builder, and an active Catalyst member building on Cardano I cannot agree, nor disagree that this proposal addresses the challenge objectives. 
The problem and the solution are clear, and the proposal and the track record of the company are within the challenge expected boundaries. 
Though looking at the company site, there's no reference to this specific solution (White label staking solution). The pitch deck does provides details and customer's stories but no evidence or link were provided to validate the claim of 150 clients using it or the Algorand grant. 
The goals provided are kind of broad and not specific, mentioning functions of the Staking service and integration to Cardano, but not how that will help this challenge to reach its goals, hindering the possibility to assess their impact. 
So I suggest to work on those details, completing the proposal as per the level of detail expected in a Catalyst proposal, for it to be assessed appropriately.
f6_assessments.q1:
As I said in my previous assessment for the MS1&2, the proposal team seems to be composed of very impressive professionals with great backgrounds and knowledge though no links where provided to be able to verify or further dig into the details of each. Several milestones and activities are being included in the proposal, which aims to produce 
Milestone #3: Mainnet deployment, testing and incorporation of final feedback - Staking and 
Milestone #4: Incorporate audit feedback and launch - Staking
But there's no timeline provided, nor any efforts of the team provided for each task/milestone so there's no way of assessing the feasibility of this proposal. Also as part of the process the proposers mention "Cardano" as an entity that will verify the deliverables and provide further guidance, but that entity does not exists within the Cardano Ecosystem, it would be really beneficial for a future proposal, that the proposers get more acquainted with the Cardano Ecosystem (Foundation, IOG, Emurgo, Catalyst) so it can be more specific on that type of assertions. 
The budget requested is in line with the challenge expected proposals, and maybe is appropriate for the successful completion of the proposal, but there's no rationale being provided on how it will be used and when in order to be able to analyze it. 
I suggest you to get back to the project board, produce all this details that are required for a Proposal to successful, in case you are voted by the community it will be key for the progress of the project and for the reports the community request later and if it is not funded, to be able to give it a try in next fund.
f6_assessments.q2:
The auditability section of this proposal is exactly the same as the previous one (MS1&2) therefore it corresponds to produce the same assessment as the previous one.
There are not measurable KPIs provided, nor dates or any information provided so that the community can properly audit and track the progress and delivery of this proposal. 
There are commitments and some methods indicated, such as a Jira board and progress and financial reports that will be provided but nothing about what will be tracked and how to know if the Return on Intention will be produced.

f6_assessments.q0: This isn't DApp, but certainly an integration and thus fits well in the challenge. A white label solution for facility native token staking with complex staking scenarios is certainly something cardano needs. It's not clear that the team is proposing an sdk port to cardano, or a platform/software as a service. An sdk port would mean we're funding Ferrum to bootstrap and port their solutions to Cardano in a form of an sdk or loosely coupled parts, which will then require manual deployment and further assembly each time a community needs as staking solution. A platform as a service would be we're funding something Ferrum will deploy with a high degree of autonomy and scalability that many teams can use to launch staking solutions. If not funded this round, I hope the team reapplies and make this distinction clearer. This is important because the delta of work between porting an sdk vs building a scalable platform is not only quite large but have very different impact potential.
f6_assessments.q1: Given that it's not clear whether the team is porting building blocks into Cardano or building a platform it's difficult to judge feasibility. It's great that deliverables were itemized and grouped into milestones. Would love to see explicit time estimations, if not milestones on the calendar, at least estimates about effort requirements for each milestone. I fear the budget may not be enough to deliver this thing. Of the technologies mentioned in the experience s of the team, algorand is one I am least familiar with. Perhaps it shares some similarity to Cardano? It would be nice to point this out, how the experience of the engineer team explicit enables them to develop on Cardano. This is important because Cardano has a very unique approach to the challenges of blockchain across the entire stack. Coming from Ethereum straight to Cardano, you might find yourself going 5 to 10x slower than your normal productivity... would would affect deliverables and milestones, perhaps the budget as well.
f6_assessments.q2: I am well verse with the SCRUM methodology of development. It is effective at keeping team on track as well as quickly raising issues that affect quality and productivity to the top to be addressed. One important primitive of SCRUM is either Milestone or Epic, a bigger grouping and window of work with clear or estimated calendar deliverables. Even though specifics isn't yet planned and jira board is still forthcoming, would have love to see these high level milestones detailed in the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
Note:
The Ferrum proposal is actually split into 2 almost identical proposals. Considering that the Impact, Audibility, and part of the Feasibility (team description + budget) sections of the Ferrum proposals are identical, my scores and justifications for one proposal also apply to this one.

The proposal is very well crafted and all aspects of why this could prove to be impactful to the Cardano community are presented in a detailed manner, with examples given to support most claims. The plan is clear and detailed and most aspects related to why the proposed Ferrum staking solution would be beneficial are much better presented than most proposals.

However, there are a few reasons why I can’t grade the impact of the proposal with a maximum score. Given that assets on Cardano are issued as native tokens, not bound by a smart contract, and that the protocol itself operates under the model of liquid staking I remain unconvinced as of now that locked staking solutions would prove to be very popular in the Cardano community. I am aware that they represent the standard operating procedure on most other blockchains, but because of the difference in the model of the base protocol, I sense that Cardano has a different culture in this regard.

Please also read the note at the end of the auditability section, as it applies to every section of the proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
(See note at the beginning of “Impact” assessment)

The milestones, roadmap, and KPIs provided are clear, detailed, and easy to follow.
The team is named, seems very adequate to implement the project, and bio for each of the members is given, but unfortunately, no external links or references are present to support the info.

The biggest downside of the feasibility section, however, is the budget breakdown, apart from a general overview of the proposed distribution there are very few details justifying the requested amount, which makes it very hard to ascertain if the budget is adequate for the needs of the project.
f6_assessments.q2:
(See note at the beginning of “Impact” assessment)

The proposal focuses on the methodology that the implementers will use internally to measure their progress, unfortunately not enough emphasis is presented on how that progress will be reported, because the KPIs and the metrics that the auditors will be able to monitor to verify the progress are not clearly stated. To some extent, the metrics and KPIs can be deduced from other sections of the proposal, but I really would have liked to see them clearly stated and presented in a manner appropriate for auditing.

The definitions of success question are very summarily answered, more details and possibly a breakdown of the envisioned success in 3, 6, and 12 months would have certainly been helpful to keep track of the project.

Note (this applies to all sections of the proposal):
While at some level I appreciate the ingenuity of the Ferrum team to split the same project into multiple development goals and submit basically identical proposals multiple times  I have deducted a point from the score of every section of the proposal for this as I feel it represents a somewhat dishonest attempt at gaming the Project Catalyst system. On the other hand, I too share the team's frustration with Project Catalyst’s clear trend of favoring “cheap” projects over much more feasible and impactful ones, that would naturally come with a higher price tag, but I don’t think that gaming the system is the solution. As a result, I have only subtracted 1 point from the score - otherwise, I would have considered an attempt to game the system as a serious infraction.
For instance what happens if only one of the proposals gets funded, as it stands I see these options:

	1)	The project doesn’t get done due to insufficient funds
	2)	The project does get made, but because of lack of funds the developers are underpaid
	3)	The sum asked for in the proposals is grossly over-budgeted to account for the possibility of a project not being funded.

Neither of them seems like a desirable option.  Moreover given the requested budget and the overall budget of the challenge, this really should not have been necessary.

f6_assessments.q0:
They are known as the Ferrum Network and they want to bring white-label staking to the Cardano ecosystem.
I feel this proposal will have a positive effect on the Cardano community. 
It will bring a staking service which should especially accelerate usage between business users, the Cardano project and their end-users.

This proposal is hard to judge because it seems fully dependent on their previous proposal "Ferrum's Staking as a Service MS1&2".
What happens if that one is not green-lit? Or vice-versa?
This is unclear to me.
f6_assessments.q2:
They will publicly display their SCRUM work-board as well as give monthly progress updates.
Since they are already a known entity in the business and have Daniel Friedman (of IOHK!) as a contact, it is very likely that they will hold to their vows.

solution: Ferrum will bring its battle tested staking solutions to Cardano. W/ 1/2 billion in lifetime TVL & over 150 clients, they're best in class.
experience: Ferrum's staking solutions have been around since 2018 w/ over 150 clients across Ethereum, Polygon, BSC, & Avalanche. Having received a grant from Algorand the ASA compatible version has been shipped for auditing. These contracts have accrued 1/2 billion in TVL w/out an exploit.
